name: Meteor M2-4
description: First fully operational Meteor-M satellite. LRPT JPEG compressor has minor issues from time to time causing pixelated imagery, the satellite has a watchdog that restarts it after a few orbits.

signals.name: LRPT
signals.description: 3 JPEG-compressed 1 km/px channels. 3x VIS during summer, 2x VIS + 1x IR during winter.

signals.name: HRPT
signals.description: Full resolution 6x MSU-MR channels at 1 km/px, MTVZA

signals.name: MTVZA dump
signals.description: MTVZA data from several orbits. Non-beamed dumps to Moscow, Novosibirsk, Khabrovsk. Narrow BPSK.

signals.name: IKFS dump
signals.description: Dumps from the IKFS instrument, not received yet - unconfirmed. Non-beamed dumps to Khabrovsk. Narrow QPSK.

signals.name: KMSS DB
signals.description: Direct broadcast from the KMSS instrument, active over Russia, Europe, possibly the Carribean and Brazil as well (unconfirmed). Wide BPSK.

signals.name: Main Dump
signals.description: KMSS/MSU-MR/Severjanin-M + MeteoSAR instrument data, only KMSS supported as of right now. Non-beamed dumps to Moscow, Novosibirsk, Khabrovsk. Wide QPSK.

name: Meteor M2-3
description: VHF antenna didn't deploy properly due to extended storage. Wide X-band transmitter has failed. LRPT JPEG compressor has minor issues from time to time causing pixelated imagery, the satellite has a watchdog that restarts it after a few orbits.

signals.name: LRPT
signals.description: 3 JPEG-compressed 1 km/px channels. 3x VIS during summer, 2x VIS + 1x IR during winter

signals.name: HRPT
signals.description: Full resolution 6x MSU-MR channels at 1 km/px, MTVZA

signals.name: Telemetry
signals.description: Telemetry broadcast, might be seen locking onto a groundstation (drifting). Currently not supported.

signals.name: MTVZA dump
signals.description: MTVZA data from several orbits. Non-beamed dumps to Moscow, Novosibirsk, Khabrovsk. Narrow BPSK.

signals.name: IKFS dump
signals.description: Dumps from the IKFS instrument, not received yet - unconfirmed. Non-beamed dumps to Khabrovsk. Narrow QPSK.

signals.name: KMSS DB
signals.description: Direct broadcast from the KMSS instrument, active over Russia, Europe, possibly the Carribean and Brazil as well (unconfirmed). Wide BPSK.

signals.name: Main Dump
signals.description: KMSS/MSU-MR/Severjanin-M + MeteoSAR instrument data, only KMSS supported as of right now. Non-beamed dumps to Moscow, Novosibirsk, Khabrovsk. Wide QPSK.

name: NOAA 15
description: This was the longest living NOAA POES satellite until being shut down due to political reasons. Decommissioning took two tries, as the satellite rebooted a few orbits after its first one. It only used a damaged emergency antenna for L-band due to the others interfering with the AMSU instrument, this made the transmission strength very weak. AVHRR came close to stalling on several occasions, but always recovered.

signals.name: APT
signals.description: 2x 4 km/px images, during day 1x IR + 1x VIS and 2x IR during night.

signals.name: HRPT
signals.description: Live full resolution operational imagery from all instruments

signals.name: GAC
signals.description: Full orbit dumps of all instruments, AVHRR only at 4 km/px. Dumped to Svalbard on every pass
